trans-unit.source: Ordinarily you must assign the returned value to a variable, but there is one situation where an automatic assignment happens. If and only if the input symbol is the only thing inside the conditional of a while statement (even if disguised as a for(;;) loop), the value is automatically assigned to the global variable $_ , destroying whatever was there previously. (This may seem like an odd thing to you, but you'll use the construct in almost every Perl script you write.) The $_ variable is not implicitly localized. You'll have to put a local $_; before the loop if you want that to happen.
trans-unit.target: Por lo general, debe asignar el valor devuelto a una variable, pero hay una situación en la que ocurre una asignación automática. Si y solo si el símbolo de entrada es lo único dentro del condicional de una instrucción while (incluso si se disfraza como un bucle for(;;) ), el valor se asigna automáticamente a la variable global $_ , destruyendo lo que estaba allí anteriormente. (Esto puede parecerle algo extraño, pero utilizará la construcción en casi todos los guiones de Perl que escriba). La variable $_ no está implícitamente localizada. Tendrá que poner un local $_; local ; antes del bucle si quieres que eso suceda.

trans-unit.source: Ordinarily you must assign the returned value to a variable, but there is one situation where an automatic assignment happens. If and only if the input symbol is the only thing inside the conditional of a while statement (even if disguised as a for(;;) loop), the value is automatically assigned to the global variable $_, destroying whatever was there previously. (This may seem like an odd thing to you, but you'll use the construct in almost every Perl script you write.) The $_ variable is not implicitly localized. You'll have to put a local $_; before the loop if you want that to happen. Furthermore, if the input symbol or an explicit assignment of the input symbol to a scalar is used as a while/for condition, then the condition actually tests for definedness of the expression's value, not for its regular truth value.

Ordinarily, if you use B::Deparse on a subroutine which has been compiled in the presence of one or more of these pragmas, the output will include statements to turn on the appropriate directives. So if you then compile the code returned by coderef2text, it will behave the same way as the subroutine which you deparsed.
trans-unit.target: Normalmente,si se utiliza B::Depender de una subrutina que ha sido compilada en presencia de uno o más de estos pragmas,la salida incluirá declaraciones para activar las directivas apropiadas.Así que si luego compilas el código devuelto por coderef2text,se comportará de la misma manera que la subrutina que has dejado.

trans-unit.source: Originally began life in May 1999 as an XS interface to the system mkstemp() function. In March 2000, the OpenBSD mkstemp() code was translated to Perl for total control of the code's security checking, to ensure the presence of the function regardless of operating system and to help with portability. The module was shipped as a standard part of perl from v5.6.1.
trans-unit.target: Originalmente comenzó su vida en mayo de 1999 como una interfaz XS para la función mkstemp()del sistema.En marzo de 2000,el código mkstemp()de OpenBSD fue traducido a Perl para un control total de la comprobación de seguridad del código,para asegurar la presencia de la función independientemente del sistema operativo y para ayudar a la portabilidad.El módulo fue enviado como una parte estándar de perl desde la v5.6.1.

trans-unit.source: Originally from the old Unix editor command for “Globally search for a Regular Expression and Print it”, now used in the general sense of any kind of search, especially text searches. Perl has a built-in grep function that searches a list for elements matching any given criterion, whereas the grep(1) program searches for lines matching a regular expression in one or more files.
trans-unit.target: Originalmente del antiguo comando del editor de Unix para "Buscar globalmente una expresión regular e imprimirla", ahora se usa en el sentido general de cualquier tipo de búsqueda, especialmente búsquedas de texto. Perl tiene una función grep incorporada que busca en una lista elementos que coincidan con cualquier criterio dado, mientras que el programa grep (1) busca líneas que coincidan con una expresión regular en uno o más archivos.

trans-unit.source: Originally from the old Unix editor command for “Globally search for a Regular Expression and Print it”, now used in the general sense of any kind of search, especially text searches. Perl has a built-in grep function that searches a list for elements matching any given criterion, whereas the grep(1) program searches for lines matching a regular expression in one or more files.

Originally the pragma was designed for the loftier goal of helping incorporate Unicode into Perl, but the approach that used it was found to be defective, and the one remaining legitimate use is for debugging when you need to non-destructively examine characters' individual bytes. Just insert this pragma temporarily, and remove it after the debugging is finished.

Otherwise, /a behaves like the /u modifier, in that case-insensitive matching uses Unicode rules; for example, "k" will match the Unicode \N{KELVIN SIGN} under /i matching, and code points in the Latin1 range, above ASCII will have Unicode rules when it comes to case-insensitive matching.
trans-unit.target: De lo contrario, /a se comporta como el modificador /u , en ese caso, la coincidencia que no distingue entre mayúsculas y minúsculas utiliza reglas Unicode; por ejemplo, "k" coincidirá con la coincidencia Unicode \N{KELVIN SIGN} debajo de /i , y los puntos de código en el rango Latin1, por encima de ASCII tendrán reglas Unicode cuando se trata de coincidencia que no distingue entre mayúsculas y minúsculas.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, use locale sets the default modifier to /l ; and use feature 'unicode_strings, or use VERSION (or higher) set the default to /u when not in the same scope as either use locale or use bytes. (use locale ':not_characters' also sets the default to /u , overriding any plain use locale .) Unlike the mechanisms mentioned above, these affect operations besides regular expressions pattern matching, and so give more consistent results with other operators, including using \U , \l , etc. in substitution replacements.
trans-unit.target: De lo contrario, use locale establece el modificador predeterminado en /l ; y use feature 'unicode_strings , o use VERSION (o superior) establezca el valor predeterminado en /u cuando no esté en el mismo ámbito que use locale o use bytes . ( use locale ':not_characters' también establece el valor predeterminado en /u , anulando cualquier use locale uso simple ). A diferencia de los mecanismos mencionados anteriormente, estos afectan las operaciones además de la coincidencia de patrones de expresiones regulares y, por lo tanto, dan resultados más consistentes con otros operadores, incluido el uso de \U , \l , etc. en reemplazos de sustitución.

trans-unit.source: Our best advice for verifying a person's mail address is to have them enter their address twice, just as you normally do to change a password. This usually weeds out typos. If both versions match, send mail to that address with a personal message. If you get the message back and they've followed your directions, you can be reasonably assured that it's real.
trans-unit.target: Nuestro mejor consejo para verificar la dirección de correo de una persona es hacer que introduzca su dirección dos veces,tal y como se hace normalmente para cambiar una contraseña.Esto normalmente elimina los errores de escritura.Si ambas versiones coinciden,envía un correo a esa dirección con un mensaje personal.Si te devuelven el mensaje y han seguido tus instrucciones,puedes estar razonablemente seguro de que es real.

PL files are normally run after pm_to_blib and include INST_LIB and INST_ARCH in their @INC , so the just built modules can be accessed... unless the PL file is making a module (or anything else in PM) in which case it is run before pm_to_blib and does not include INST_LIB and INST_ARCH in its @INC . This apparently odd behavior is there for backwards compatibility (and it's somewhat DWIM).
trans-unit.target: Los archivos PL normalmente se ejecutan después de pm_to_blib e incluyen INST_LIB e INST_ARCH en su @INC , por lo que se puede acceder a los módulos recién construidos ... a menos que el archivo PL esté creando un módulo (o cualquier otra cosa en PM), en cuyo caso se ejecuta antes pm_to_blib y no incluye INST_LIB e INST_ARCH en su @INC . Este comportamiento aparentemente extraño está ahí por compatibilidad con versiones anteriores (y es algo DWIM).

trans-unit.source: PL files are normally run after pm_to_blib and include INST_LIB and INST_ARCH in their @INC, so the just built modules can be accessed... unless the PL file is making a module (or anything else in PM) in which case it is run before pm_to_blib and does not include INST_LIB and INST_ARCH in its @INC. This apparently odd behavior is there for backwards compatibility (and it's somewhat DWIM). The argument passed to the .PL is set up as a target to build in the Makefile. In other sections such as postamble you can specify a dependency on the filename/argument that the .PL is supposed (or will have, now that that is is a dependency) to generate. Note the file to be generated will still be generated and the .PL will still run even without an explicit dependency created by you, since the all target still depends on running all eligible to run.PL files.

trans-unit.source: Pack and unpack can operate in two modes: character mode (C0 mode) where the packed string is processed per character, and UTF-8 byte mode (U0 mode) where the packed string is processed in its UTF-8-encoded Unicode form on a byte-by-byte basis. Character mode is the default unless the format string starts with U . You can always switch mode mid-format with an explicit C0 or U0 in the format. This mode remains in effect until the next mode change, or until the end of the () group it (directly) applies to.
trans-unit.target: Empaquetar y desempaquetar pueden operar en dos modos: modo de caracteres (modo C0 ) donde la cadena empaquetada se procesa por carácter, y modo de byte UTF-8 ( modo U0 ) donde la cadena empaquetada se procesa en su forma Unicode codificada en UTF-8 en byte a byte. Modo de caracteres es el valor por defecto a menos que la cadena de formato comienza con U . Siempre puede cambiar el modo de formato medio con un C0 o U0 explícito en el formato. Este modo permanece en efecto hasta el siguiente cambio de modo, o hasta el final de la () grupo que (directamente) se aplica a.

trans-unit.source: Pack and unpack can operate in two modes: character mode (C0 mode) where the packed string is processed per character, and UTF-8 byte mode (U0 mode) where the packed string is processed in its UTF-8-encoded Unicode form on a byte-by-byte basis. Character mode is the default unless the format string starts with U. You can always switch mode mid-format with an explicit C0 or U0 in the format. This mode remains in effect until the next mode change, or until the end of the () group it (directly) applies to.

trans-unit.source: Package lexicals declared with my in the main block of a package using AutoLoader will not be visible to auto-loaded subroutines, due to the fact that the given scope ends at the __END__ marker. A module using such variables as package globals will not work properly under the AutoLoader.

Un módulo que utiliza variables como paquetes globales no funcionará correctamente en el Autocargador .

trans-unit.source: Package lexicals declared with my in the main block of a package using AutoLoader will not be visible to auto-loaded subroutines, due to the fact that the given scope ends at the __END__ marker. A module using such variables as package globals will not work properly under the AutoLoader.

Package names are sometimes an exception to this rule. Perl informally reserves lowercase module names for "pragma" modules like integer and strict . Other modules should begin with a capital letter and use mixed case, but probably without underscores due to limitations in primitive file systems' representations of module names as files that must fit into a few sparse bytes.
trans-unit.target: Los nombres de los paquetes son a veces una excepción a esta regla. Perl reserva informalmente nombres de módulos en minúsculas para módulos "pragma" como integer y strict . Otros módulos deben comenzar con una letra mayúscula y usar mayúsculas y minúsculas, pero probablemente sin guiones bajos debido a las limitaciones en las representaciones de los sistemas de archivos primitivos de los nombres de los módulos como archivos que deben caber en unos pocos bytes dispersos.

trans-unit.source: Package names are sometimes an exception to this rule. Perl informally reserves lowercase module names for "pragma" modules like integer and strict. Other modules should begin with a capital letter and use mixed case, but probably without underscores due to limitations in primitive file systems' representations of module names as files that must fit into a few sparse bytes.

trans-unit.source: Packages claim that there won't be errors on calls to or from packages explicitly marked as safe by inclusion in @CARP_NOT , or (if that array is empty) @ISA . The ability to override what @ISA says is new in 5.8.
trans-unit.target: Los paquetes afirman que no habrá errores en las llamadas hacia o desde paquetes marcados explícitamente como seguros por inclusión en @CARP_NOT , o (si esa matriz está vacía) @ISA . La capacidad de anular lo que dice @ISA es nueva en 5.8.

trans-unit.source: Packages claim that there won't be errors on calls to or from packages explicitly marked as safe by inclusion in @CARP_NOT, or (if that array is empty) @ISA. The ability to override what @ISA says is new in 5.8.

Packages may themselves contain package separators, as in $OUTER::INNER::var . This implies nothing about the order of name lookups, however. There are no relative packages: all symbols are either local to the current package, or must be fully qualified from the outer package name down. For instance, there is nowhere within package OUTER that $INNER::var refers to $OUTER::INNER::var . INNER refers to a totally separate global package.
trans-unit.target: Los paquetes pueden contener separadores de paquetes, como en $OUTER::INNER::var . Sin embargo, esto no implica nada sobre el orden de las búsquedas de nombres. No hay paquetes relativos: todos los símbolos son locales para el paquete actual o deben estar completamente calificados desde el nombre del paquete externo hacia abajo. Por ejemplo, no hay ningún lugar dentro del paquete OUTER donde $INNER::var refiera a $OUTER::INNER::var . INNER se refiere a un paquete global totalmente separado.

trans-unit.source: Packages may themselves contain package separators, as in $OUTER::INNER::var. This implies nothing about the order of name lookups, however. There are no relative packages: all symbols are either local to the current package, or must be fully qualified from the outer package name down. For instance, there is nowhere within package OUTER that $INNER::var refers to $OUTER::INNER::var. INNER refers to a totally separate global package. The custom of treating package names as a hierarchy is very strong, but the language in no way enforces it.

Packages should NOT be released with succeeding TODO tests. As soon as a TODO test starts working, it should be promoted to a normal test, and the newly working feature should be documented in the release notes or in the change log.
trans-unit.target: Os pacotes NÃO devem ser libertados com testes de TODO sucesso.Assim que um teste TODO começar a funcionar,deve ser promovido a um teste normal,e a nova funcionalidade a funcionar deve ser documentada nas notas de lançamento ou no registo de alterações.

trans-unit.source: Packages such as the AutoLoader and SelfLoader that delay loading of subroutines within packages can create problems with package lexicals defined using my(). While the vars pragma cannot duplicate the effect of package lexicals (total transparency outside of the package), it can act as an acceptable substitute by pre-declaring global symbols, ensuring their availability to the later-loaded routines.
trans-unit.target: Los paquetes como AutoLoader y SelfLoader que retrasan la carga de subrutinas dentro de los paquetes pueden crear problemas con los léxicos de los paquetes definidos con my() . Si bien el pragma vars no puede duplicar el efecto de los léxicos del paquete (transparencia total fuera del paquete), puede actuar como un sustituto aceptable al pre-declarar símbolos globales, asegurando su disponibilidad para las rutinas cargadas posteriormente.

trans-unit.source: Packages such as the AutoLoader and SelfLoader that delay loading of subroutines within packages can create problems with package lexicals defined using my(). While the vars pragma cannot duplicate the effect of package lexicals (total transparency outside of the package), it can act as an acceptable substitute by pre-declaring global symbols, ensuring their availability to the later-loaded routines.

trans-unit.source: Parse a Perl arithmetic expression. This may contain operators of precedence down to the bit shift operators. The expression must be followed (and thus terminated) either by a comparison or lower-precedence operator or by something that would normally terminate an expression such as semicolon. If flags has the PARSE_OPTIONAL bit set, then the expression is optional, otherwise it is mandatory. It is up to the caller to ensure that the dynamic parser state ("PL_parser" et al) is correctly set to reflect the source of the code to be parsed and the lexical context for the expression.

La secuencia de la declaración termina cuando se encuentra una llave de cierre o un final de archivo en un lugar donde una nueva declaración podría haber comenzado válidamente. Depende de la persona que llama asegurarse de que el estado del analizador dinámico ( PL_parser et al) esté configurado correctamente para reflejar la fuente del código que se va a analizar y el contexto léxico de las declaraciones.

trans-unit.source: Particular block scope types store extra per-type information. For example, CXt_SUB stores the currently executing CV, while the various for loop types might hold the original loop variable SV. On scope exit, the per-type data is processed; for example the CV has its reference count decremented, and the original loop variable is restored.

Particularly consider setting $Term::ANSIColor::EACHLINE if you are interleaving output to standard output and standard error and you aren't flushing standard output (via autoflush() or setting $|). If you don't, the code to reset the color may unexpectedly sit in the standard output buffer rather than going to the display, causing standard error output to appear in the wrong color.

trans-unit.source: Pass arrays and hashes by reference, not by value. For one thing, it's the only way to pass multiple lists or hashes (or both) in a single call/return. It also avoids creating a copy of all the contents. This requires some judgement, however, because any changes will be propagated back to the original data. If you really want to mangle (er, modify) a copy, you'll have to sacrifice the memory needed to make one.
trans-unit.target: Pasar matrices y hashes por referencia,no por valor.Para empezar,es la única manera de pasar varias listas o hashes (o ambos)en una sola llamada/devolución.También evita crear una copia de todos los contenidos.Sin embargo,esto requiere cierto juicio,porque cualquier cambio se propagará de nuevo a los datos originales.Si realmente quieres destrozar (er,modificar)una copia,tendrás que sacrificar la memoria necesaria para hacer una.

trans-unit.source: Pass arrays as references so more parameters can be added later (it's also faster). Convert functions into methods where appropriate. Split large methods into smaller more flexible ones. Inherit methods from other modules if appropriate.

Passing new options to the $walker is the easiest way to change amongst any pre-defined styles (the ones you add are automatically recognized as options), and is the only way to alter rendering order without calling compile again. Note however that rendering state is still shared amongst multiple $walker objects, so they must still be used in a coordinated manner.
trans-unit.target: Pasar nuevas opciones al $walker es la forma más fácil de cambiar entre cualquier estilo predefinido (los que añades se reconocen automáticamente como opciones),y es la única forma de alterar el orden de renderización sin llamar a la compilación de nuevo.Sin embargo,ten en cuenta que el estado de renderización sigue siendo compartido entre múltiples objetos $walker,por lo que deben seguir utilizándose de forma coordinada.

Patches are reviewed and discussed on GitHub or the p5p list. Simple, uncontroversial patches will usually be applied without any discussion. When the patch is applied, the ticket will be updated and you will receive email.

Patches are reviewed and discussed on the p5p list. Simple, uncontroversial patches will usually be applied without any discussion. When the patch is applied, the ticket will be updated and you will receive email. In addition, an email will be sent to the p5p list.

trans-unit.source: Patches may be applied by the pumpkin holder without the explicit cooperation of the module author if and only if they are very minor, time-critical in some fashion (such as urgent security fixes), or if the module author cannot be reached. Those patches must still be given back to the author when possible, and if the author decides on an alternate fix in their version, that fix should be strongly preferred unless there is a serious problem with it. Any changes not endorsed by the author should be marked as such, and the contributor of the change acknowledged.
trans-unit.target: El soporte de calabaza puede aplicar parches sin la cooperación explícita del autor del módulo si,y sólo si,son muy pequeños,de alguna manera críticos para el tiempo (como arreglos de seguridad urgentes),o si no se puede contactar con el autor del módulo.Esos parches deben devolverse al autor cuando sea posible,y si el autor se decide por un arreglo alternativo en su versión,ese arreglo debe ser muy preferible,a menos que haya un problema grave con él.Cualquier cambio que no sea aprobado por el autor deberá ser marcado como tal,y se reconocerá al colaborador del cambio.

Si esto no es lo que desea, use \Q para interpolar una variable literalmente.

trans-unit.source: Pay special attention to METHODS FOR PARSING AND PROCESSING and to the objects described in Pod::InputObjects. The former describes the gory details and parameters for how to customize and extend the parsing behavior of Pod::Parser. Pod::InputObjects provides several objects that may all be used interchangeably as parse-trees. The most obvious one is the Pod::ParseTree object. It defines the basic interface and functionality that all things trying to be a POD parse-tree should do. A Pod::ParseTree is defined such that each "node" may be a text-string, or a reference to another parse-tree. Each Pod::Paragraph object and each Pod::InteriorSequence object also supports the basic parse-tree interface.
trans-unit.target: Preste especial atención a los MÉTODOS DE PARSING Y PROCESAMIENTO y a los objetos descritos en Pod :: InputObjects . El primero describe los detalles y parámetros sangrientos sobre cómo personalizar y extender el comportamiento de análisis de Pod :: Parser . Pod :: InputObjects proporciona varios objetos que pueden usarse indistintamente como árboles de análisis. El más obvio es el objeto Pod :: ParseTree . Define la interfaz básica y la funcionalidad que deben hacer todas las cosas que intentan ser un árbol de análisis POD. Un Pod :: ParseTree se define de manera que cada "nodo" puede ser una cadena de texto o una referencia a otro árbol de análisis. Cada objeto Pod :: Párrafo y cadaEl objeto Pod :: InteriorSequence también admite la interfaz de árbol de análisis básica.

trans-unit.source: Peephole optimizations are done by calling the function pointed to by the global variable PL_peepp . By default, PL_peepp just calls the function pointed to by the global variable PL_rpeepp . By default, that performs some basic op fixups and optimisations along the execution-order op chain, and recursively calls PL_rpeepp for each side chain of ops (resulting from conditionals). Extensions may provide additional optimisations or fixups, hooking into either the per-subroutine or recursive stage, like this:
trans-unit.target: Las optimizaciones de mirilla se realizan llamando a la función apuntada por la variable global PL_peepp . Por defecto, PL_peepp solo llama a la función apuntada por la variable global PL_rpeepp . De forma predeterminada, realiza algunas optimizaciones y reparaciones de operaciones básicas a lo largo de la cadena de operaciones de orden de ejecución, y llama de forma recursiva a PL_rpeepp para cada cadena lateral de operaciones (resultante de condicionales). Las extensiones pueden proporcionar optimizaciones o correcciones adicionales, conectándose a la etapa por subrutina o recursiva, como esta:

trans-unit.source: Perceptive Perl hackers may have noticed that a for loop has a return value, and that this value can be captured by wrapping the loop in a do block. The reward for this discovery is this cautionary advice: The return value of a for loop is unspecified and may change without notice. Do not rely on it.
trans-unit.target: Los hackers perceptivos de Perl pueden haber notado que un bucle for tiene un valor de retorno, y que este valor puede capturarse envolviendo el bucle en un bloque do . La recompensa por este descubrimiento es este consejo de advertencia: el valor de retorno de un bucle for no está especificado y puede cambiar sin previo aviso. No confies en eso.

trans-unit.source: Perceptive Perl hackers may have noticed that a for loop has a return value, and that this value can be captured by wrapping the loop in a do block. The reward for this discovery is this cautionary advice: The return value of a for loop is unspecified and may change without notice. Do not rely on it.
Perform a stream ping. If the tcp connection isn't already open, it opens it. It then sends some data and waits for a reply. It leaves the stream open on exit.

Perform a udp echo ping. Construct a message of at least the one-byte sequence number and any additional data bytes. Send the message out and wait for a message to come back. If we get a message, make sure all of its parts match. If they do, we are done. Otherwise go back and wait for the message until we run out of time. Return the result of our efforts.

trans-unit.source: Performs the default fixup of the arguments part of an entersub op tree. This consists of applying list context to each of the argument ops. This is the standard treatment used on a call marked with & , or a method call, or a call through a subroutine reference, or any other call where the callee can't be identified at compile time, or a call where the callee has no prototype.
trans-unit.target: Realiza la corrección predeterminada de los argumentos que forman parte de un árbol de operaciones de entersub . Consiste en aplicar contexto de lista a cada una de las operaciones de argumento. Este es el tratamiento estándar que se usa en una llamada marcada con & , o una llamada a un método, o una llamada a través de una referencia de subrutina, o cualquier otra llamada en la que no se puede identificar al destinatario en tiempo de compilación, o en una llamada en la que el destinatario no tiene prototipo.

trans-unit.source: Performs the default fixup of the arguments part of an entersub op tree. This consists of applying list context to each of the argument ops. This is the standard treatment used on a call marked with &, or a method call, or a call through a subroutine reference, or any other call where the callee can't be identified at compile time, or a call where the callee has no prototype.

Performs the fixup of the arguments part of an entersub op tree based on a subroutine prototype. This makes various modifications to the argument ops, from applying context up to inserting refgen ops, and checking the number and syntactic types of arguments, as directed by the prototype. This is the standard treatment used on a subroutine call, not marked with & , where the callee can be identified at compile time and has a prototype.
trans-unit.target: Realiza la reparación de los argumentos que forman parte de un árbol de operaciones entersub basado en un prototipo de subrutina. Esto hace varias modificaciones a las operaciones de argumento, desde la aplicación de contexto hasta la inserción de operaciones de refgen y la verificación del número y los tipos sintácticos de argumentos, según lo indicado por el prototipo. Este es el tratamiento estándar utilizado en una llamada de subrutina, no marcado con & , donde el destinatario puede identificarse en tiempo de compilación y tiene un prototipo.

trans-unit.source: Performs the fixup of the arguments part of an entersub op tree based on a subroutine prototype. This makes various modifications to the argument ops, from applying context up to inserting refgen ops, and checking the number and syntactic types of arguments, as directed by the prototype. This is the standard treatment used on a subroutine call, not marked with &, where the callee can be identified at compile time and has a prototype.

Performs the fixup of the arguments part of an entersub op tree either based on a subroutine prototype or using default list-context processing. This is the standard treatment used on a subroutine call, not marked with & , where the callee can be identified at compile time.
trans-unit.target: Realiza la reparación de los argumentos que forman parte de un árbol de operaciones entersub , ya sea basándose en un prototipo de subrutina o utilizando el procesamiento de contexto de lista predeterminado. Este es el tratamiento estándar que se usa en una llamada de subrutina, no marcado con & , donde se puede identificar al destinatario en el momento de la compilación.

trans-unit.source: Performs the fixup of the arguments part of an entersub op tree either based on a subroutine prototype or using default list-context processing. This is the standard treatment used on a subroutine call, not marked with &, where the callee can be identified at compile time.

Perl 5 has extension mechanisms, modules and XS, specifically to avoid the need to keep changing the Perl interpreter. You can write modules that export functions, you can give those functions prototypes so they can be called like built-in functions, you can even write XS code to mess with the runtime data structures of the Perl interpreter if you want to implement really complicated things.
trans-unit.target: Perl 5 tiene mecanismos de extensión,módulos y XS,específicamente para evitar la necesidad de seguir cambiando el intérprete de Perl.Puedes escribir módulos que exporten funciones,puedes dar a esas funciones prototipos para que puedan ser llamadas como funciones incorporadas,incluso puedes escribir código XS para meterte con las estructuras de datos en tiempo de ejecución del intérprete de Perl si quieres implementar cosas realmente complicadas.

trans-unit.source: Perl 5 is developed by a community, not a corporate entity. Every change contributed to the Perl core is the result of a donation. Typically, these donations are contributions of code or time by individual members of our community. On occasion, these donations come in the form of corporate or organizational sponsorship of a particular individual or project.
trans-unit.target: El Perl 5 es desarrollado por una comunidad,no por una entidad corporativa.Cada cambio contribuido al núcleo de Perl es el resultado de una donación.Típicamente,estas donaciones son contribuciones de código o tiempo por miembros individuales de nuestra comunidad.En ocasiones,estas donaciones vienen en forma de patrocinio corporativo u organizacional de un individuo o proyecto en particular.

trans-unit.target: El Perl 5 fue compilado y probado con éxito:

trans-unit.source: Perl 5.10 added three specials, ${^MATCH} , ${^PREMATCH} , and ${^POSTMATCH} to do the same job but without the global performance penalty. Perl 5.10 only sets these variables if you compile or execute the regular expression with the /p modifier.
trans-unit.target: Perl 5.10 agregó tres especiales, ${^MATCH} , ${^PREMATCH} y ${^POSTMATCH} para hacer el mismo trabajo pero sin la penalización de rendimiento global. Perl 5.10 solo establece estas variables si compila o ejecuta la expresión regular con el modificador /p .
